results.title: Open Enrollment Begins for Affordable Care Act Health Plans
results.abstract: Pandemic-era help with the monthly insurance premium costs continues through 2025.
des_facet: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

results.title: Writing ‘Maid’ Pulled Stephanie Land Out of Poverty. She’s Fine Now, Right?
results.abstract: Despite writing a best seller that became a hit Netflix series, Ms. Land says she still worries about her job security.

results.title: TransUnion Failed to Quickly Place or Remove Freezes on Credit Reports
results.abstract: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau accused the credit bureau, one of three major credit reporting agencies, of “lying to consumers.”

results.title: More Than 400,000 Student Loan Borrowers Had Wrong Monthly Payments
results.abstract: The Education Department said miscalculations had caused many borrowers to see higher monthly payments than they actually owed.

multimedia.caption: More than 28 million federal student loan borrowers returned to repayment this month after a pandemic-related relief program put their monthly bills on pause for nearly four years.

results.title: How to Take Advantage of a Health Savings Account
results.abstract: Insurance plans with high deductibles may seem unappealing, but the savings accounts that often come with them offer significant tax benefits.

results.title: Social Security Benefits Will Rise 3.2% in 2024
results.abstract: Millions of Social Security beneficiaries, from retirees to disabled workers, will receive the cost-of-living adjustment, which is far less than last year’s but still higher than average.

results.title: A New Effort to Make College Aid Offers Easy to Understand
results.abstract: After years of criticism about financial aid letters that are confusing and sometimes misleading, about 400 schools have agreed to bring “clarity” to their communication.

results.title: It’s Time to Pay Your Student Loans. What Happens if You Fall Behind?
results.abstract: Missed payments will be reported as a forbearance rather than as delinquencies. But your credit score could still be affected.

multimedia.caption: Federal student loan borrowers who miss payments over the next year should see minimal changes to their credit standing.

results.title: What Should You Do if Hotels Don’t Warn You About Strikes?
results.abstract: There is recourse for customers who arrive at a hotel and are surprised to find a boisterous picket line waiting to greet them.

results.title: What New York homeowners and renters should know about flood insurance.
results.abstract: Standard homeowners’ and renters’ policies don’t cover damages that can be caused by the kind of heavy rains that hit New York City on Friday.

multimedia.caption: It may be too late for those in the New York City area to buy policies to cover damages caused by the torrential rains that hit the city on Friday, but others may want to consider doing so for future protection.
multimedia.copyright: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times

results.title: Consumer Agency Moves to Ban Medical Debt From Credit Reports
results.abstract: Millions of Americans owe money to doctors and hospitals, and that debt can affect their ability to get loans or even a job.

results.title: New York Drivers Are Paying More for Car Insurance. Here’s Why.
results.abstract: Policyholders should check the details of their auto insurance, which will automatically enroll them in extra spousal coverage — even if they’re single.

results.title: The Rising Costs of Owning a Car
results.abstract: Everything is going up — buying, financing, insurance and maintenance. The average annual cost of ownership, by one estimate, is $12,000.
des_facet: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks

results.title: The Simple Nudge That Raised Median Donations by 80%
results.abstract: A start-up used the Hebrew word “chai” and its numerical match, 18, to bump up giving amounts. What magic number would do the same for you?

results.title: Beware Companies Selling Credit ‘Repair’ Services
results.abstract: Consumers have a right to dispute mistakes on their credit reports. But if they’ve made late payments, that can’t be erased, consumer experts say.

results.title: Why Some Ex-Workers at Bed Bath & Beyond Face 401(k) Losses
results.abstract: Federal law generally protects retirement savings when a company files for bankruptcy. But that’s not always the case.

results.title: Student Loan Payments Are Due Again. Here Are 5 Things to Know.
results.abstract: A three-year payment pause has ended in October. A more affordable repayment plan is available, and some borrowers will receive a fresh start.

multimedia.caption: The Georgetown University campus. During an adjustment period from Oct. 1 to Sept. 31, 2024, borrowers won’t be considered delinquent if they miss a payment on their federal student loan.

results.title: Biden’s New Student Loan Repayment Plan Is Open. Here’s How to Enroll.
results.abstract: The income-driven plan, SAVE, will reduce payments for millions of borrowers, and more will qualify for $0 payments.

results.title: Credit Card Balances Hit New Peak
results.abstract: Debt rose to more than $1 trillion in the second quarter, a report found — a sign of financial strain for some, even before student loan payments resume.
org_facet: Federal Reserve Bank of New York

results.title: Letter to a Young Crypto Enthusiast (or the Merely Curious)
results.abstract: An ever-growing number of young people, males in particular, have bought cryptocurrencies. Here’s some advice, without the finger-wagging.
